HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 1 HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM DATE: August 14, 2024 TO: Darrell West | Bonneville MPO DaNeil Jose | Bonneville MPO FROM: Aaron Berger, PE | DKS Associates SUBJECT: BMPO High-Capacity Roadways Study Project #22174-000 This memorandum summarizes the process used to identify, evaluate, and select the recommended high-capacity roadway system for the BMPO area. The memo includes: • Summary of Prior Work – Baseline Needs Evaluation Summary, Study Purpose and Need Statement, and summary Public Outreach completed to date • Alternatives Development and Evaluation – process and outcomes from expressway and strategic arterial concept development and evaluation of alternatives • Recommendations – Presents the recommended new expressways and strategic arterials, including recommended changes to functional classification throughout the BMPO area SUMMARY OF PRIOR WORK The work completed during the High-Capacity Roadway Study (HCRS) to date is summarized in the following sections: • Baseline Needs Evaluation Summary • Purpose and Need Statement • Public Outreach Summary BASELINE NEEDS EVALUATION SUMMARY The baseline needs for the BMPO area roadway system are described in detail in the Baseline Conditions and Needs Technical Memorandum.1 The needs evaluation used the BMPO travel demand model for years 2022 (existing), 2035, and 2050 conditions, flagging key congested corridors throughout the region. This evaluation included planned projects from the LRTP through the year 2050, including widening projects on several arterial corridors and the I-15 to US 20 Connector (see Figure 1). These Baseline projects were documented in the study Methods and 1 BMPO HCRS Baseline Conditions and Needs and Technical Memorandum, September 2023 HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 2 Assumptions Memorandum.2 The planning level cost estimates for these proposed improvements total $325 Million, excluding the cost of the I-15 to US 20 Connector, The I-15/US20 connector project was included in the modelling. FIGURE 1: BMPO BASELINE PROJECTS (2022, 2035, 2050) 2 BMPO HCRS Methods and Assumptions Memo, March 2023 HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 3 The future traffic conditions of the BMPO area were forecasted based on the demographic projections and baseline network assumptions presented in Baseline Conditions Memorandum. The needs analysis focused on the year 2050 Baseline Conditions. To identify levels of congestion and network constraints, estimate traffic Level of Service (LOS) was used to compare the daily traffic volumes to the roadway capacity, based on roadway type and number of lanes. The 2050 Baseline BMPO model LOS and estimated Average Daily Traffic (ADT) volumes are summarized in Figure 2. FIGURE 2: 2050 BASELINE LOS AND ADT As shown in Figure 2, the BMPO Area is expected to experience increased congestion in the future, even with assumed significant investment in expanding and adding to existing roadways. System wide, drivers in the BMPO Area are forecasted to experience 82% more delay per trip by the year 2050. HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 4 The BMPO Area system wide levels of congested roadway, LOS E (at capacity) and LOS F (over capacity) are summarized by lane miles in Table 1. TABLE 1: CONGESTED LANE MILES SUMMARY YEAR % LANE MILES LOS E % LANE MILES LOS F % LANE MILES DEFICIENT (LOS E AND F) 2022 2.6% 1.9% 4.5% 2050 8.3% 6.9% 15.2% As shown in Table 1, by the year 2050 the total miles of congested roadway within the BMPO area roadway system is estimated to more than triple, despite the improvements assumed in the 2050 Baseline Scenario to include the projects in the LRTP. The primary areas of need identified in the Baseline Needs analysis include: • Existing and future congestion on segments of critical arterial corridors such as: o 17th Street (both existing and future conditions) o Ammon Road (both existing and future conditions) o Iona Road (both existing and future conditions) o 5th East (both existing and future conditions) o Lincoln Road (future conditions) o 25th East (future conditions) o Sunnyside Road (future conditions) o 5th West (future conditions) • Constrained East-West river crossings, including 2050 daily traffic demand projected to increase by 94% over present-day conditions, include: o Broadway (LOS D) o Pancheri (LOS F) o Sunnyside (LOS E) o 65th S (LOS D with assumed widening of the existing bridge to double capacity) • The Sunnyside Road/I-15 Interchange – trips using the interchange are expected to increase from 17,000 to 45,000 per day by the year 2050. This increase includes the baseline assumption that the 65th S bridge is widened. Without this project, Sunnyside Interchange traffic would increase even more. • Traffic growth on rural roads towards the foothills to the East, including the rural segments of Sunnyside Road, 17th Street 45th East, Ammon Road, and 65th South are expected to exceed capacity due to the growth projected in the southern portion of the BMPO Area. PROJECT PURPOSE AND NEEDS STATEMENT The roadway congestion needs identified in the Future Baseline Evaluation were combined with other identified needs including safety, access, and active transportation themes from the most HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 5 recent BMPO LRTP to create the High-Capacity Roadway Study (HCRS) Needs Statement, as follows: “Lack of safe, efficient, and equitable access for all modes of travel from new growth areas within the BMPO area to regional activity centers and highway facilities, with increasing pass-through travel on congested arterial corridors.” Based on the study needs statement, the HCRS Purpose Statement was then defined as follows: “Proactively plan and develop comprehensive multi-modal high-capacity roadway corridors and supporting connections, optimizing future transportation investments to help alleviate traffic congestion on existing arterial corridors and enhance overall regional mobility.” Both the Purpose and Need Statements establish the approach to the alternatives development process. PUBLIC OUTREACH SUMMARY The Exiting and Future Baseline system evaluation results and study Purpose and Need Statement were shared with the Public in an Open House event on November 14, 2023. Public feedback from this event identified the following additional key themes: • Lack of active transportation facilities • Congestion on arterial corridors, particularly Ammon Road • Pass/Cut-thru traffic on local streets • Need for coordinated signal timing on arterials • Utility of roundabouts on arterials • Speeding on rural arterials • Need for beltway system to reduce congestion These needs were also considered where applicable to the project purpose statement during the subsequent alternatives screening and evaluation process. ALTERNATIVES DEVELOPMENT AND EVALUATION The alternatives development and evaluation process followed four distinct steps: 1. Develop initial Expressway Alternatives 2. Fatal Flaw (Level 1) Screening of Expressway Alternatives (with the Steering Committee only or including elected officials?) Concern was expressed by elected officials in the last Joint TAC Police Board meeting giving indicators that we might have to go back to this step 3. Evaluation (Level 2) of Expressway Alternatives 4. Develop and Evaluate Strategic Arterial Alternatives HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 6 INITIAL EXPRESSWAY ALTERNATIVES An expressway is a limited access, median-separated, high speed (55 mph or more) facility. US 20 through Idaho Falls currently operates as an expressway facility. Expressways may include grade separations/interchanges, particularly in urbanized areas, but can also be full access at-grade intersections, albeit spaced at 1-mile minimum distances. An expressway will contain a minimum of two lanes per direction. The initial expressway alternatives were developed using a combination of ideas from the Steering Committee, project team, and the public, as well as concepts proposed in the “Idaho Falls Arterial Loop: Economic Assessment” and the “Transportation System Alternatives Study.” These expressway concepts were intended to serve future growth areas surrounding the currently urbanized BMPO areas while also providing higher speed, higher capacity alternatives to existing congested arterial corridors. Note that by nature of their proposed locations, the expressways would not be expected to provide significant relief to current congestion issues in the more fully built out areas within the BMPO, as the new facilities would be too far out of direction to pull trips from these roadways. The expressway alternatives were intended to provide both capacity for new development and increase resiliency of nearby congested arterials against future growth. The following initial Expressway Alternatives were proposed for Level 1 Screening (See Figure 3): • North Concept o North Expressway Alternative 1 – New Expressway located approximately on the 81st North Alignment, from I-15 to US 26. This concept would include a new interchange on I-15 and a new Snake River crossing. • South Concepts o South Expressway Alternative 1 – New Expressway located approximately along the 65th South existing alignment, from I-15 to 45th East (Crowley). This concept would involve re-aligning the 65th South Corridor between 15th East and 25th East. o South Expressway Alternative 2 – New Expressway located approximately halfway between 65th South and 81st South, connecting I-15 to 45th East (Crowley). This alternative would follow the 65th South existing alignment from I-15 through US 91. o South Expressway Alternative 3 – New Expressway located approximately along the 65th South existing alignment, but routing to the north-east at 25th East, ultimately connecting to 45th East (Crowley) near Sunnyside Road. This concept is identical to South Expressway Alternative 1 from I-15 to 25th East. • East o East Expressway Alternative 1 – New Expressway located approximately ¼ mile east of 55th East, from just north of the 65th South/45th East (Crowley) intersection to the US 26/55th East intersection. • West o West Expressway Alternative 1 – New Expressway connecting the planned I-15/US 20 Connector system interchange to the I-15/45th West/65th South interchange. This alignment would approximately follow the existing 45th West alignment from 17th North to 65th South. HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 7 Note that these initial concepts were very high-level planning alignments, and more specific details related to the alignment locations and geometry were saved for alternatives passing the subsequent Level 1 (Fatal Flaw) Screening. FIGURE 3: INITIAL EXPRESSWAY CONCEPTS HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 8 Two additional alternatives were considered and dismissed based on clear feasibility constraints: • 45th East Expressway (65th S to US 26) – the existing land use, constrained ROW, and access conditions on this corridor led to this alternative being deemed infeasible by the Stakeholder Committee • 55th East Expressway (45th E near 65th S to US 26) – similar to 45th East, the constrained ROW, and access conditions on this corridor led to this alternative being deemed infeasible by the Stakeholder Committee EXPRESSWAY ALTERNATIVES LEVEL 1 SCREENING The HCRS Streeting Committee performed the Level 1 (Fatal Flaw) Screening of the initial expressway alternatives. The key Level 1 Screening Criteria considered were: • Physical Constraints – consideration of prohibitive terrain features such as steep grades • Traffic Utility – consideration of the project purpose and need related to identified congestion needs • ROW/property Impacts – Potential to create large scale property acquisitions in already built out neighborhoods and subdivisions • Access Impacts – existing roadway and driveway access for expressway alignments following current roadway corridors Using these criteria, the Steering Committee screened out the following expressway alternatives: • North Expressway Alternative 1 – This concept was screened out due to minimal anticipated traffic utility towards the HCRS Purpose and Need. Under 2050 Baseline Conditions, the I-15 to US 20 Connector project provides surplus capacity for east-west traffic in this area, and the proposed expressway corridor would not be targeting any clear needs. In addition, the ROW impacts along 81st N and the feasibility of constructing another system level interchange on I-15 were determining factors in screening out this alternative. • South Expressway Alternative 1 – This alternative was screened out due to access impacts along the existing 65th South corridor, which includes many driveways and already abuts housing subdivision connections. • South Expressway Alternative 3 – This alternative was also screened out due to access impacts along the existing 65th South corridor as well as conflicts with subdivisions when connecting from 65th south across Ammon Road and onto 49th East (Crowley) • East Expressway Alternative 1 – This alternative was screened out due to property impacts and grade constraints for the segment from 45th East to the proposed north-south alignment, particularly conflicts at Sunnyside Road The remaining Expressway Alternatives (South Expressway Alternative 2 and West Expressway Alternative 1) were advanced to the Level 2 Evaluation. EXPRESSWAY ALTERNATIVES LEVEL 2 EVALUATION The two expressway alternatives advanced to the Level 2 Evaluation (South Alt 2 and West Alt 1) were analyzed in the 2050 BMPO travel demand model to estimate the potential traffic benefits and independent utility of these proposed corridors. Each corridor was also evaluated to determine the HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 9 high-level key design constraints and potential ROW, access, and design challenges that the proposed expressway would likely entail. WEST EXPRESSWAY ALTERNATIVE EVALUATION The West Expressway Alignment was refined to include curves that met AASHTO standards for the anticipated speeds (55 mph) of the new facility. The northern terminus of the proposed expressway was connected to the yet to be constructed I-15/US 20 Connector as the fourth leg of the system interchange. At the southern terminus, the expressway follows the 45th W alignment into the 65th S/I-15 interchange. The West Expressway Alternative was added to the BMPO 2050 Baseline network and run as an independent scenario under 2050 conditions. As this was a high-level evaluation of the viability of this proposed expressway, the initial coding assumptions emphasized capacity, speed, and throughput. These coding assumptions do not represent the likely expressway configuration but do portray the ability of the proposed facility to draw trips away from other congested corridors. The arterial intersections with the proposed expressway were either modeled as grade separations (overpass/underpass) or interchanges, described as follows: • Old Butte Rd/N 26th W – Coded as an overpass/underpass • 35th W – Coded as an interchange • 57th W – Coded as an overpass/underpass • W 17th N – Coded as an interchange • US 20 – Coded as an interchange • 17th Street S – Coded as an overpass/underpass • W 33rd S – Coded as an interchange • W 49th S – Coded as an overpass/underpass To better understand the traffic benefits of the West Expressway Alternative, the change in daily traffic volume between the year 2050 West Expressway Alternative and the Baseline Scenario was mapped and analyzed (See Figure 4). HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 10 FIGURE 4: WEST EXPRESSWAY VS BASELINE 2050 TRAFFIC VOLUME CHANGE As shown in Figure 4, the West Expressway draws traffic away from the I-15 and US 20 West, reducing daily traffic on these corridors by up to 15%. The expressway essentially provides a US 20 bypass around Idaho Falls. The expressway also pulls traffic away from the congested I-15/Sunnyside Road interchange, reducing traffic at this location by 5%. Additional localized increases on roadways such as 33rd S, 49th S, and Broadway are driven be assumed reduced access HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 11 to the 45th West corridor, which would then reallocate trips to these east-west corridors. Overall, these reallocated future trips are not expected to create significant capacity issues on these east-west corridors. The West Expressway 2050 BMPO model LOS and estimated Average Daily Traffic (ADT) volumes are summarized in Figure 5 (without the South Expressway Alternative). FIGURE 5: 2050 WEST EXPRESSWAY LOS AND ADT As shown in Figure 5, the West Expressway does not directly address any of the critical 2050 Baseline LOS issues. This proposed expressway does provide significant regional route redundancy by providing an alternate US 20 route, and also provides additional capacity to support growth west of the Snake River. HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 12 A high-level assessment of the corridor for expressway feasibility indicated the challenges summarized in Table 2. TABLE 2: WEST EXPRESSWAY KEY CHALLENGES CHALLENGE SEGMENT POTENTIAL MITIGATIONS PRIVATE DRIVEWAYS 65th S to 49th S Shift expressway alignment west of 45th W ½ Mile south of US 20 Shift expressway alignment slightly west, extend old S 45th Rd W alignment south as a frontage connection CONSTRAINED ROW 17th S/45th W Consider shifting alignment east to bypass existing privates and commercial structures NEW ROW NEEDED 17th N to I-15/US 20 Connector Interchange Refine alignment for this corridor to provide basis for ROW buffer, ensuing future development does not build over the proposed corridor 17th N to 65th S Ensure incoming development along 45th W leaves sufficient ROW setbacks to accommodate an expressway cross section 65th S/I-15 Interchange ROW needs for potential system interchange SOUTH EXPRESSWAY ALTERNATIVE EVALUATION The South Expressway Alignment was refined to include curves that met AASHTO standards for the anticipated speeds (55 mph) of the new facility. The western terminus of the proposed expressway follows the existing 65th S alignment and connects into the 65th S/I-15 interchange. At the eastern terminus, the expressway ties into 45th E (Crowley). The South Expressway Alternative was added to the BMPO 2050 Baseline network and run as an independent scenario under 2050 conditions. As this was a high-level evaluation of the viability of this proposed expressway, similar to the West Expressway, the initial coding assumptions emphasized capacity, speed, and throughput. These coding assumptions do not represent the likely expressway configuration but do portray the ability of the proposed facility to draw trips away from other congested corridors. The arterial intersections with the proposed expressway were either modeled as grade separations (overpass/underpass) or interchanges, described as follows: • 1600 Rd/81 S – Overpass/Underpass • US 91 – Interchange • Jameston Rd – Overpass/Underpass • 5th W – Overpass/Underpass • 5th E (Holmes) – Interchange HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 13 • 15th E – Overpass/Underpass • 25th E – Interchange • Ammon Rd – Overpass/Underpass In addition, the 65th S/I-15 interchange capacity was assumed to be expanded as part of the South Expressway Alternative, with the existing roundabouts widened to multi-lane and the existing overpass expanded to four lanes. To better understand the traffic benefits of the South Expressway Alternative, both South Expressway Alternative 1 and Alternative 2 were evaluated. South Expressway Alternative 1 was modeled to determine whether shifting the expressway further south significantly decreased the traffic benefits. In addition, the West Expressway Alternative was included with both South Expressway Scenarios to better understand the traffic impacts at the 65th S/I-15 interchange. The change in daily traffic volume between the year 2050 South Expressway Alternative 1, Alternative 2, and the Baseline Scenario are shown in Figure 6 and Figure 7. HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 14 FIGURE 6: SOUTH EXPRESSWAY ALTERNATIVE 1 VS BASELINE 2050 TRAFFIC VOLUME CHANGE HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 15 FIGURE 7: SOUTH EXPRESSWAY ALTERNATIVE 2 VS BASELINE 2050 TRAFFIC VOLUME CHANGE HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 16 As shown in both figures, the south expressway pulls traffic off multiple congested corridors, reducing 2050 traffic demand on Sunnyside Road by approximately 12%, and on 17th Street by approximately 8%. Based on these findings, shifting the south expressway approximately ½ mile south of 65th S was determined to provide similar traffic benefits to the expressway alternative on the existing 65th S alignment. Note that there are additional shifts of north-south traffic between parallel corridors. These shifts are driven by the modeled access points from arterials onto the expressway, and result in some small north-south traffic shifts farther from the expressway, such as on to Woodruff north of 25th S. The South Expressway 2050 BMPO model LOS and estimated Average Daily Traffic (ADT) volumes are summarized in Figure 8. FIGURE 8: 2050 SOUTH EXPRESSWAY LOS AND ADT HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 17 As shown in Figure 8, the South Expressway reduces future congestion on Sunnyside Road, reducing travel time on this corridor by more than 12%, and on 17th Street by more than 7%. In addition, this alternative reduces traffic demand on the 65th S corridor. A high-level assessment of the corridor for expressway feasibility indicated the challenges summarized in Table 3. TABLE 3: SOUTH EXPRESSWAY KEY CHALLENGES CHALLENGE SEGMENT POTENTIAL MITIGATIONS PLANNED DEVELOPMENT Jameston Rd to 5th West (Ivywood West) Shift alignment south, shift reverse curves west to bypass new subdivision COMMERCIAL ACCESS I-15 to US 91 Provide backage/frontage connections to consolidate access along this segment GEOGRAPHIC CONSTRAINTS Snake River Construct second bridge to double capacity, coordinate with County to determine jurisdiction Gravel pit southeast of US 91/65th S Build interchange at existing US 91/65th S intersection, tighten reverse curves to avoid gravel pit and shift alignment ½ mile south by Jameston Rd CONFLICTS WITH EXISTING LAND USES Fairgrounds Shift alignment further south to bypass Ivywood Platted Development Shift alignment further south to bypass CONFLICTS WITH EXISTING INFRASTRUCTURE S 1st E/5th E curves Shift alignment further south to tie into 1st S with more minimal ROW impacts 65th S/I-15 Interchange Interchange would need to be expanded (multi-lane roundabouts, 4-lane bridge) to accommodate expressway traffic, could need additional ROW if ultimate design is a system interchange NEW ROW NEEDED US 91 to 45th E (Crowley) Refine alignment for this corridor to provide basis for ROW buffer, ensuing future development does not build over the proposed corridor EXPRESSWAY ALTERNATIVES LEVEL 2 EVALUATION Following the evaluation of the expressway alternatives, the project team and Steering Committee identified potential candidate corridors for strategic arterials. Strategic arterials would be five to seven lane roadways, with access limited to ½ mile intersection spacing. Intersections could be HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 18 signal or roundabout controlled, with roundabout control working particularly well in locations where eliminating access points, particularly existing driveways, is not feasible. The initial strategic arterials proposed for consideration are shown in Figure 9. FIGURE 9: PROPOSED STRATEGIC ARTERIALS HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 19 The strategic arterials were added to the BMPO 2050 Baseline network and run as an independent scenario under 2050 conditions without expressways. The coding of the proposed corridors consisted of removing/revising centroid connections (neighborhood access) onto the proposed strategic arterials. These changes reflected potential access restrictions along the corridors. Corridor speeds were also increased to reflect reduced intersection impedance. Note that the strategic arterials were first tested independently from the expressways to understand their utility, but the ultimate goal is to have the strategic arterials combined with expressways to serve future traffic needs. To better understand the traffic benefits of the Strategic Arterials, the change in daily traffic volume between the year 2050 Strategic Arterials Alternative and the Baseline Scenario was mapped and analyzed (See Figure 10). HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 20 FIGURE 10: STRATEGIC ARTERIAL ALTERNATIVE VS BASELINE 2050 TRAFFIC VOLUME CHANGE The strategic arterial corridors draw traffic demand from parallel corridors, with 65th S, Lincoln Rd, 25th E, and 45th E in particular drawing additional traffic demand and providing some relief to adjacent corridors such as Ammon Road (up to 13% reduction) and 1st St (up to 12% reduction). The Strategic Arterial 2050 BMPO model LOS and estimated Average Daily Traffic (ADT) volumes are summarized in Figure 11. HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 21 FIGURE 11: 2050 STRATEGIC ARTERIAL LOS AND ADT As shown in Figure 11, the Strategic Arterial Alternative improves travel times on the following routes: • 65th S (east of US 91) • 35th W • 45th E HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 22 • 49th S • 45th N Overall, the strategic arterials provide system wide benefit, and that benefit is further augmented when coupled with the south expressway. A high-level assessment of the corridors for strategic arterial feasibility indicated the following key challenges: • 65th S Corridor Challenges o Driveway access – numerous private driveways, particularly between Ammon Road and 45th E o Local subdivision access, including > Maggie Dr > 9 W > S 9th W > S 12th W > Limousin Ave > Glass Mountain Blvd > Sommer Dr o Land Use – Fairgrounds o Geometry – offset intersection at 25th E • Sunnyside Road Corridor Challenges o Local road access, particularly east of 25th E o Constrained ROW – East of 25th E o Existing private driveway access • Lincoln Road Corridor Challenges o Unknown future tie-in to existing US 20 corridor o Commercial Access points west of 25th E o Private driveway access from 25th E to Ammon Rd • 49th N Corridor Challenges o Need to coordinate with ITD US 26 corridor project, particularly at Beaches Corner o Private driveways from Ammon Rd to 45th E • 33rd N Corridor Challenges o Private driveway access near 26th W/Old Butte Rd • 45th W Corridor Challenges o Private driveway access south of 49th S, near 17th S, south of US 20 • 25th E Corridor Challenges o Commercial access near Iona Road and US 26 o Private accesses north of US 26 • 45th E Corridor Challenges HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 23 o Limited ROW/canal conflicts, particularly north of Lincoln Rd o Private drive access, particularly for ½ mile south of Iona Rd INITIAL HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY SYSTEM The West Expressway was initially recommended for inclusion as an opportunity to provide long-term (30+ year) capacity for growth west of I-15. Based on this recommendation, 45th W and 33rd N were not initially recommended as strategic arterials. The South Expressway was initially recommended for inclusion in the high-capacity roadway system due to both the 25-year benefits to adjacent corridors such as Sunnyside and 65th S as well as the potential to serve larger future growth needs as the urbanized areas continue to extend to the south. Due to the South Expressway recommendation, 65th S was not initially recommended as a strategic arterial, but rather was recommended to become a minor arterial with a 3-lane cross section. The Old Butte Road Corridor was recommended for inclusion as a strategic arterial as this corridor completes an inner loop connection and provides support for the more near-term development likely to occur west of the Snake River. All other proposed strategic arterials corridors were included in the initial recommended high-capacity roadway system. In addition, 5th W (Freeman Rd/E River Rd) north of US 20 showed capacity issues under 2050 conditions, and is recommended to be upgraded from a Minor Arterial to a Major Arterial from US 20 to 65th N. The full initial recommended scenario is shown in Figure 12. HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 24 FIGURE 12: INITIAL HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY SYSTEM HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 25 The traffic benefits of the Initial High-Capacity Roadway scenario were evaluated by adding the proposed expressways and strategic arterials to the 2050 Baseline Scenario. The change in daily traffic volume between the year 2050 Initial High-Capacity Roadway and the Baseline Scenario was mapped along with the ADT and LOS (See Figure 13 and Figure 14). FIGURE 13: INITIAL HIGH-CAPACITY SYSTEM VS BASELINE 2050 TRAFFIC VOLUME CHANGE HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 26 FIGURE 14: INITIAL HIGH-CAPACITY SYSTEM ADT AND LOS As shown in Figure 14, the initial High-Capacity System improves several corridors, including Sunnyside Road, 65th S, Iona Road, and 45th E. Key system performance metrics are summarized in Table 4. HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 27 TABLE 4: CONGESTED LANE MILES SUMMARY YEAR % LANE MILES LOS E % LANE MILES LOS F % LANE MILES DEFICIENT (LOS E AND F) 2022 - EXISTING 2.6% 1.9% 4.5% 2050 - BASELINE 8.3% 6.9% 15.2% 2050 – INITIAL HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY SYSTEM 7.2% 5.8% 13.0% The Initial High-Capacity System area wide benefits are somewhat muted by the capacity constraints of the existing strategic arterial corridors. These corridors do have opportunities for additional capacity enhancement, particularly with coordinated signal timings on the signalized corridors, and widening on to existing five-lane segments at key locations. These proposed corridors will help keep the regional traffic movements off the local system, enhancing opportunities for parallel low stress active transportation corridors, reduce the risk of neighborhood cut-through traffic attempting to bypass arterial congestion, and provide opportunities for safer transit access. Additional evaluation at the corridor level considered the traffic operations benefits of limiting future access to the strategic arterial corridors as the surrounding areas develop and build out. These benefits were estimated based on the proportion of each corridor currently undeveloped, and the Highway Capacity Manual (HCM) travel time and segment density (congestion) reductions associated with reduced access. Existing corridors surrounded by more built out adjacent land uses realize less future benefit, as many of the access decisions on the urban segments of these corridors have already been made. Key initial benefits and future project considerations of the Initial High-Capacity Roadway System are summarized by corridor as follows: • South Expressway o Benefits > Reduces future traffic demand on Sunnyside Road, improving travel times by 12% > Reduces future traffic demand on 17th Street by approximately 8%, improves travel time by 7% > Reduces future traffic demand on 65th S by 56%. This corridor could now be built out to a 3-lane (rather than 5-lane) minor arterial standard > Provides long-term east-west capacity, providing potential to serve a broader variety of land uses along the new corridor o Future Project Considerations > Need to increase capacity at I-15/65th S interchange > New Snake River Bridge HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 28 > Interchange at US 91/South Expressway – design must balance 65th S access, railroad tracks/ROW, and gravel pit impacts > Minimize impacts to the platted Ivywood development > Incorporate 5th E future extension > Avoid Fairgrounds property impacts > Tie-in with 45th E should include a transition zone down to a strategic arterial. This could include a roundabout at 45th E/65th S/South Expressway. • West Expressway o Benefits > Reduces future traffic demand on I-15 and US 20 by approximately 15% > Reduces future north-south travel time on the east side by approximately 30% > Provides long-term capacity to land east of I-15 o Future Project Considerations > Coordinate tie-in to I-15/US 20 Connector > Plan for future interchange at US 20/45th W > Complete preliminary design for alignment from I-15 to US 20 W to determine ROW needs > Expand 65th S/I-15 Interchange to incorporate multi-lane roundabouts/system interchange • Sunnyside Road Strategic Arterial Re-classification o Benefits > Potential 5% decrease in future travel time > Improved corridor safety (reduced conflicts) > Reduced traffic demand on 17th Avenue and 49th S o Future project considerations > Planned expansion from 2 to 5 lanes from Ammon Road to 45th E should include access restrictions wherever possible > Implement east-west signal timing coordination along the corridor > Feasibility study and preliminary design for future interchange expansion at I-15/Sunnyside Road • Lincoln Road Strategic Arterial Re-classification o Benefits > Potential 5% decrease in future travel time > Improved corridor safety (reduced conflicts) > Reduced traffic demand on Iona Road and 1st Avenue o Future project considerations > Coordinate west tie-in with old US 20 corridor future configuration > Leverage existing roundabouts (u-turns) to limit access to right-in/right-out where feasible HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 29 > Build future widening project from Ammon Road to 45th E to strategic arterial cross section and access standards • 49th N Strategic Arterial Re-classification o Benefits > Potential 25% decrease in future travel time > Improved corridor safety (reduced conflicts) > Reduced traffic demand on Iona Road o Future project considerations > Coordinate with ITD US 26 corridor project at Beaches Corner to facilitate east-west arterial travel > Ensure incoming schools along the corridor prioritize local roadway access over connection to 49th N • Old Butte Road Strategic Arterial Re-classification o Benefits > Potential 5% decrease in future travel time > Improved corridor safety (reduced conflicts) > Reduced intra-city travel on I-15 o Future project considerations > Ensure any future extension of Old Butte Road meets strategic arterial access restrictions > Consider alternate (narrower) cross sections for segments with potential FAA/Airport conflicts • 25th E Strategic Arterial Re-classification o Benefits > Potential 5% decrease in future travel time > Improved corridor safety (reduced conflicts) > Reduces future traffic demand on Ammon Road and Woodruff Ave o Future project considerations > Ensure widening projects south of Sunnyside Road meet strategic arterial access restrictions • 45th E Strategic Arterial Re-classification o Benefits > Potential 10% decrease in future travel time > Improved corridor safety (reduced conflicts) > Reduced traffic demand on Ammon Road o Future project considerations > Consider adding a north-south residential roadway from railroad tracks to Iona Road east of 45th E, providing properties currently fronting 45th E with alternate access > Support roundabouts at key intersections along the corridor with corresponding access restrictions HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 30 • 5th W (re-classify to Principal Arterial) o This corridor shows increased future traffic and congestion, mostly due to the proposed I-15/US 20 connector project. To accommodate this increased traffic, the 5th W classification is recommended to be upgraded to Principal Arterial, and a new project should be considered to widen this corridor to five lanes from the existing five-lane section near MK Simpson Blvd to 65th N. This improvement should be coordinated with the I-15/US 20 Connector project. The initial findings and recommendations from the evaluation of alternatives were shared with the local jurisdiction staff and elected representatives. Further input was received regarding ROW constraints, expressway viability, and needed connections, and this input was used to develop the Final Recommended High-Capacity Roadway Network. FINAL HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY NETWORK The input received from local jurisdictions throughout the BMPA indicated ROW and land use constraints that rendered the West Expressway alternative inviable. Therefore, the 45th W and 33rd N Strategic Arterials were added back into the High-Capacity Roadway system as part of the final recommendation. The key benefits and future project considerations for these corridors are summarized as follows: • 45th W Strategic Arterial Re-classification o Benefits > Potential 25% decrease in future travel time > Improved corridor safety (reduced conflicts) > Reduced intra-city travel on I-15 o Future project considerations > Plan for future interchange at US 20/45th W • 33rd N Strategic Arterial Re-classification o Benefits > Potential 5% decrease in future travel time > Improved corridor safety (reduced conflicts) > Reduced traffic demand US 20 (I-15 to 45th W) • Future project considerations o If the I-15 to US 20 connector contains a full access west side connection at I-15, ensure that this access connects to 33rd W Additional adjustments were made to the reclassification recommendations for the other strategic arterial corridors, ensuring all strategic arterials start and end at either equal or higher classification facilities. The South Expressway concept was further refined, with a preliminary alignment and initial interchange footprint concepts added to develop an estimated range of potential impact for the corridor. This area is shown in Figure 15. HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY STUDY • ALTERNATIVES MEMORANDUM • AUGUST 2024 31 FIGURE 15: SOUTH EXPRESSWAY CONCEPT PROJECT NAME • NAME OF MEMORANDUM • DATE These changes were all incorporated into the Final Recommended High-Capacity Roadway System, which is shown in Figure 16. FIGURE 16: FINAL RECOMMENDED HIGH-CAPACITY ROADWAY SYSTEM This Final Recommended High-Capacity Roadway System will be incorporated into the BMPO Access Management Plan, and then passed on to local jurisdictions for adoption. The South Expressway must next be advanced through sufficient schematic design to allow for right-sized ROW preservation along the future corridor, and to develop feasible project phasing for this expressway. The Strategic Arterials cross section standards from the updated Access Management Plan will be PROJECT NAME • NAME OF MEMORANDUM • DATE used to guide current and upcoming planned projects on these corridors, ensuring that new construction and incoming development adheres to access spacing and roadway standards that enhance and maintain the capacity of the corridor.

document1.context: reduction in daily VMT per capita

document3.object: percentage of lane miles at LOS F in BMPO area
document3.context: percentage of lane miles at over capacity

tasks.question: San Francisco saw a 13% decrease in daily VMT per capita in August 2024. In the same month, the U.S. experienced a 0.5% month-over-month decrease in housing starts. By 2050, the BMPO area is expected to have 6.9% of lane miles at over capacity (LOS F). Find the result of subtracting the VMT decrease in San Francisco from the percentage of lane miles at LOS F in the BMPO area, and then multiplying by the housing starts decrease.
tasks.solution:
def solve():
    # Extracted numerical values from the document
    vmt_decrease_sf = 13  # VMT decrease in San Francisco
    housing_starts_decrease = 0.5  # Housing starts decrease in the U.S.
    lane_miles_los_f = 6.9  # Lane miles at LOS F in BMPO area

    # Step 1: Subtract the VMT decrease from lane miles at LOS F
    difference = lane_miles_los_f - vmt_decrease_sf

    # Step 2: Multiply the result by the housing starts decrease
    answer = difference * housing_starts_decrease

    return answer

Harsher penalties, civil suits possible for speeding drivers in DC under newly passed bill

Thomas Robertson  | trobertson@wtop.com

February 7, 2024, 6:12 AM
D.C. would have the authority to boot and tow vehicles repeatedly caught speeding by cameras under new legislation unanimously passed by the city’s council Tuesday.
Council member Charles Allen introduced the Strengthening Traffic Enforcement, Education, and Responsibility (STEER) Act of 2024. The bill would also allow for “speed governors,” devices that can prevent drivers from exceeding a certain speed, to be installed in certain vehicles.
Passage of the STEER Act comes after the District saw 52 traffic deaths in 2023, an increase from 35 in 2022.
“It’s obvious right now that a significant number of drivers do not fear accountability for speeding, driving recklessly, or driving drunk. And why should they? Nothing about their experience tells them there are consequences,” Allen said in a news release. “That’s about to change now that the Council has spoken clearly.”
The STEER Act would establish a new points system for vehicles repeatedly caught speeding. If a vehicle accumulates 10 points in a six-month window, it immediately becomes eligible for booting and towing. Under the bill, points are accumulated as follows:
Allen’s office said in a news release that D.C. cameras issued more than 1 million tickets for cars going 11-15 mph over the speed limit.
The point system would apply to any vehicle, regardless of where it’s registered.
“Speed governors” would come into play for drivers whose license was suspended or revoked because of excessive speeding, including reckless driving. The first time a driver is required to enroll in the program, they would have to use the device for one year. The length of enrollment increases by one year for each subsequent conviction, with a fourth conviction resulting in lifelong enrollment.
The STEER Act would also empower D.C.’s Office of the Attorney General to bring civil suits against drivers from anywhere who have large balances of unpaid moving violations.
“We must redouble our efforts to crack down on dangerous drivers who put pedestrians, cyclists, and other drivers at risk,” D.C. Attorney General Brian Schwalb said.
It was revealed in November that 335 drivers who should have been enrolled in D.C.’s Ignition Interlock Program did not have the devices installed in their vehicles. Allen’s office said the bill would address the Department of Motor Vehicles’ notification failures that led to offending drivers slipping through the cracks.
“Dangerous driving is far too common in every DC neighborhood,” Allen said in a news release. “The bill approved today will create real, common sense accountability measures to reduce speeding and reckless behavior in our neighborhoods and close loopholes blocking accountability.”
Mayor Muriel Bowser and Congress still need to sign off on the legislation before it becomes law.

International Journal for Multidisciplinary Research (IJFMR) E-ISSN: 2582-2160 ● Website: www.ijfmr.com ● Email: editor@ijfmr.com IJFMR240214871 Volume 6, Issue 2, March-April 2024 1 Smart Traffic Control System Using Artificial Intelligence Paul Shruti Kanailal1, Lavanya E2, G. Anbu Selvi3, N. Senthamilarasi4 1,2BE CSE-AI, Sathyabama Institute of Science and Technology Chennai, India 3,4M. Tech, Ph.D, Sathyabama Institute of Science and Technology Chennai, India Abstract AI-powered transportation systems represent a transformative leap in urban mobility management, leveraging real-time data processing to dynamically adjust traffic flow, significantly reducing fuel consumption, emissions, and idling times. These systems excel in swiftly responding to potential hazards at intersections, minimizing accidents by identifying risks and prioritizing emergency vehicles for immediate clearance, potentially saving lives. Their adaptability and learning capabilities optimize commute times, energy consumption, and traffic efficiency at intersections, fostering sustainable urban environments. Through machine learning algorithms, they pre-emptively address bottlenecks, refining traffic dynamics, and enhancing economic productivity. Additionally, by facilitating seamless vehicle-infrastructure communication, these systems enable personalized route recommendations, optimized traffic signal timings, and rerouting strategies, paving the way for a smart, interconnected urban ecosystem prioritizing efficiency, safety, and sustainability, revolutionizing urban transportation management. Keywords: Traffic System, Management, Vehicle Monitoring, Intelligent Traffic Monitoring System, Fuzzy Logic, Machine Learning. I. INTRODUCTION Achieving a more precise and adaptive estimate of green signal time is crucial for optimizing traffic flow and minimizing delays in metropolitan cities. To achieve it a unique approach is used, dividing vehicles into distinct categories and employing advanced object detection techniques like YOLO (You Only Look Once). Object detection algorithms like YOLO enable the system to accurately identify and count the number of vehicles in real-time. This process provides valuable data on the volume and distribution of vehicles in each direction at a particular intersection. By categorizing vehicles, the system gains a nuanced understanding of the diverse traffic mix, considering the varying sizes, speeds, and acceleration characteristics of different vehicle types. Once this real-time data is obtained, the system becomes adaptive, dynamically adjusting the timers of traffic signals based on the observed volume of vehicles in each category and direction. This adaptability is a key feature that distinguishes the system from traditional static traffic signal setups. Rather than relying on predetermined signal timings, the system responds in real-time to the actual traffic conditions, maximizing the efficiency of the green light duration. The adaptive adjustment of signal timings has several advantages. Firstly, it minimizes unnecessary International Journal for Multidisciplinary Research (IJFMR) E-ISSN: 2582-2160 ● Website: www.ijfmr.com ● Email: editor@ijfmr.com IJFMR240214871 Volume 6, Issue 2, March-April 2024 2 delays and waiting times for vehicles at the intersection. By precisely tailoring the green signal duration to the current traffic demands, the system ensures that traffic is cleared more swiftly than it would be under a static signal system. This not only reduces congestion but also enhances overall traffic throughput. Furthermore, the dynamic adjustment of signal timings has a cascading effect on fuel consumption and pollution. With reduced waiting times and smoother traffic flow, vehicles spend less time idling at intersections, leading to lower fuel consumption and emissions. This environmental benefit aligns with the broader goal of creating a more sustainable and eco-friendly urban transportation system. In summary, the integration of object detection techniques and adaptive signal timing based on real- time traffic data represents a sophisticated and effective approach to traffic management. By leveraging technology to categorize and quantify vehicles, and subsequently optimizing signal timings, the system significantly improves traffic efficiency, reduces congestion, lowers fuel use, and contributes to a cleaner and more sustainable urban environment. II. LITERATURE REVIEW 1. proposes a solution using video processing. The video from the live feed is processed before being sent to the servers where a C++ based algorithm is used to generate the results. Hard code and Dynamic coded methodologies are compared, in which the dynamic algorithm showed an improvement of 35%. 2. The paper [4] has proposed an MPC (Model predictive control) which will be used on the highway and focuses on roadside control. The pa- per basically provides information on how MPC can be applied for speed control and lane allocation. It basically works with the lane requirements and speed allocation. x The paper states that every car running on the highway can be allocated a certain speed for the particular time. x The time span given and the lane given to the vehicle is independent. 3. System developed for the main intersections of the road. Microcontroller used is Beagle Bone Black/Rasp Pi, algorithm used is Haar Cascade. The system proves that it can minimize traffic mobbing and reduce waiting time of vehicles in front of traffic signals. To make real time analysis of traffic in modern cities,the authors of this project have configured and coupled actual traffic images taken with micro controller and guarantees that the average waiting time of vehicles in front of traffic signal will be lesser than the present traffic control system. 4. Smart Traffic the board framework is a one of the significant elements for a brilliant city. As of now traffic the executives and ready frameworks are not fulfilling the needs of STMS. It is more costly and profoundly configurable to offer better assistance for traffic executives. This paper proposes a minimal expense Real-Time brilliant traffic Management System to offer better support by sending traffic markers to refresh the traffic subtleties right away. Minimal expense vehicle identifying sensors are implants in the street for each 500 meters or 1000 meters. IoT is being utilized to get traffic information rapidly and send it for handling. 5. In order to perform intelligent decision- making based on the traffic circumstances on the present lane and its neighboring lane in a four-lane intersection, Mittal and Chawla (2020) proposed a hybrid neuro- fuzzy adaptive traffic light system. The ANFIS system was implemented using Sugeno. The system was broken down into three parts: lane selection, timing adjustments for the green signal extension, and system training. ANFIS model performance was compared to those of fuzzy systems and fixed timing systems. The experimental findings demonstrated that the suggested ANFIS system International Journal for Multidisciplinary Research (IJFMR) E-ISSN: 2582-2160 ● Website: www.ijfmr.com ● Email: editor@ijfmr.com IJFMR240214871 Volume 6, Issue 2, March-April 2024 3 outperformed other systems in terms of efficiency. III. EXISTING SYSTEM Real-time Adaptability and Responsiveness: Traditional traffic management systems often operate on fixed schedules, lacking the agility to swiftly respond to dynamically changing traffic conditions. This limitation results in suboptimal traffic flow, heightened congestion, and prolonged wait times at intersections The introduction of real-time adaptability revolutionizes this landscape by enabling traffic signals to dynamically adjust based on the current volume and distribution of vehicles. This not only improves overall traffic efficiency but also significantly reduces delays, leading to a more responsive and adaptive urban transportation system. Environmental Efficiency One of the critical drawbacks of existing traffic systems is their reliance on predetermined schedules, which may lead to inefficiencies during unexpected traffic congestion or periods of low vehicle volumes. Real-time adaptability in traffic signals addresses this issue by optimizing green light durations based on actual demand. This dynamic adjustment minimizes unnecessary stops and idling, contributing to improved environmental efficiency. Reduced fuel consumption and emissions become tangible benefits of this adaptive approach, aligning with broader sustainability goals for urban environments. Enhanced Safety Features: The reliance of traditional traffic management on basic sensors and manual interventions poses challenges in rapidly changing or emergency situations. Real-time adaptive systems, however, enhance safety features by quickly analyzing and responding to evolving traffic conditions. This proactive approach significantly lowers the likelihood of accidents, fostering a safer urban transportation landscape. The integration of advanced technologies for real-time decision-making marks a crucial step toward achieving a transportation system that prioritizes the well-being of commuters and pedestrians. Automated Response to Emergency Vehicles: Existing traffic systems often rely on manual activation of emergency signals and limited pre- emption systems, which can be insufficient in heavy traffic or densely populated areas. Real-time adaptive systems bring a transformative shift by autonomously detecting and prioritizing emergency vehicles. This automated response ensures immediate and seamless clearance at intersections, facilitating the swift movement of emergency services through traffic. In emergency situations, this capability can prove critical, potentially saving lives by expediting the timely arrival of crucial services. In conclusion, the shift from fixed-schedule traffic management systems to real-time adaptive systems represents a significant advancement in urban transportation. This evolution addresses inefficiencies, enhances environmental sustainability, improves safety features, and automates responses to emergency situations, collectively contributing to a more efficient, responsive, and safer urban transportation infrastructure. IV. PROPOSED SYSTEM Upon implementing the proposed model, a paradigm shift occurs in the way we assess the time for a vehicle to reach its destination. The system utilizes advanced technologies, such as real-time traffic International Journal for Multidisciplinary Research (IJFMR) E-ISSN: 2582-2160 ● Website: www.ijfmr.com ● Email: editor@ijfmr.com IJFMR240214871 Volume 6, Issue 2, March-April 2024 4 data, object detection techniques, and adaptive signal timings. It dynamically adjusts estimations based on the current volume, distribution of vehicles, and other relevant factors. This ensures a more accurate and responsive assessment of the time needed for vehicles to traverse specific routes. Following implementation, a crucial step involves comparing the time periods before and after the introduction of the model. This comparative analysis allows for a comprehensive evaluation of the model's effectiveness in optimizing traffic flow, reducing delays, and improving overall transportation efficiency. By identifying the areas of improvement, city planners and traffic management authorities can fine-tune the model for further enhancements. A notable feature of the proposed model is its ability to create a "Green Corridor" for emergency vehicles. Traditional systems may require manual activation of emergency signals or face limitations in heavy traffic. The new model, however, autonomously detects and prioritizes emergency vehicles, dynamically adjusting traffic signal timings to facilitate their swift passage. This not only ensures rapid response times during emergencies but also contributes to enhanced safety and potentially life- saving intervention. 1. Data Collection and Processing: Comprehensive data is collected from various sources, including traffic cameras, sensors, and connected vehicles. Machine learning algorithms preprocess and analyze this data in real-time to understand current traffic conditions, identifying factors such as vehicle volume, speed, and congestion levels. 2. Object Detection Techniques: Advanced object detection techniques, such as YOLO (You Only Look Once), are employed to accurately identify and categorize different types of vehicles, pedestrians, and potential hazards at Fig. 1. System Architecture intersections. This provides granular insights into the composition and movement of traffic, allowing for precise adjustments in the traffic control strategy. International Journal for Multidisciplinary Research (IJFMR) E-ISSN: 2582-2160 ● Website: www.ijfmr.com ● Email: editor@ijfmr.com IJFMR240214871 Volume 6, Issue 2, March-April 2024 5 3. AI-Based Decision-Making: Machine learning models are trained to make intelligent decisions based on the analyzed data. These decisions include dynamically adjusting traffic signal timings to optimize flow and reduce congestion. The system continuously learns from real-time data, adapting its decision-making processes to evolving traffic patterns and unforeseen events. 4. Adaptive Signal Timings: The core of the system lies in its ability to dynamically adapt signal timings based on the current traffic conditions. This adaptability ensures that the system responds in real-time to fluctuations in traffic volume, minimizing delays and optimizing overall traffic flow. 5. Emergency Vehicle Prioritization: The system incorporates algorithms that autonomously detect and prioritize emergency vehicles. This enables the creation of a "Green Corridor" for swift passage during emergencies, enhancing response times and potentially saving lives. V. RESULT The implementation of a Smart Traffic Control Management System utilizing AI yields significant and multifaceted results, bringing about transformative changes in urban transportation dynamics. This section discusses the key outcomes and implications of integrating AI into traffic control. Optimized Traffic Flow and Reduced Congestion: One of the primary outcomes of the AI-powered system is the optimization of traffic flow. By dynamically adjusting signal timings based on real- time data, the system minimizes unnecessary stops and delays, leading to a smoother and more efficient traffic movement. Reduced congestion is a direct consequence, positively impacting the overall mobility of vehicles within the urban landscape. Decreased Commute Times and Enhanced Efficiency: The AI-driven system's adaptability and learning capabilities result in decreased commute times for both individual commuters and public transportation. Through continuous refinement of its algorithms, the system learns from traffic patterns, making informed decisions to maximize the efficiency of signal timings. This improvement not only benefits commuters but also enhances economic productivity by reducing time spent in transit. Environmental Benefits and Reduced Emissions: The dynamic adjustments in traffic signal timings contribute to decreased idling times at intersections. This reduction in unnecessary stops translates to lower fuel consumption and, consequently, reduced emissions. The environmental impact of the AI- powered system aligns with sustainability goals, fostering a greener and more eco-friendly urban environment. Improved Safety Features: The integration of AI enhances safety features within the traffic management system. Real-time object detection and hazard identification enable quick responses to potential dangers at intersections. The system's ability to prioritize emergency vehicles ensures rapid clearance, potentially preventing accidents and saving lives in critical situations. Overall, the AI system contributes to a safer urban transportation infrastructure. VI. CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORK In conclusion, the implementation of a Smart Traffic Control Management System using AI marks a International Journal for Multidisciplinary Research (IJFMR) E-ISSN: 2582-2160 ● Website: www.ijfmr.com ● Email: editor@ijfmr.com IJFMR240214871 Volume 6, Issue 2, March-April 2024 6 transformative leap in urban transportation. The system's dynamic adaptability optimizes traffic flow, reduces congestion, and enhances overall efficiency. Commute times are minimized, contributing to increased economic productivity, while environmental benefits manifest through reduced emissions and fuel consumption. The integration of AI enhances safety features, identifying hazards and prioritizing emergency vehicles for swift response. While challenges and refinements are anticipated, the continuous evolution of this technology holds great promise for creating smarter, safer, and more sustainable urban environments. The AI-driven traffic control system stands as a beacon for the future of transportation management, where real- time responsiveness and data-driven decision- making pave the way for more efficient and livable cities. VII. FUTURE WORK The future work for Smart Traffic Control Management Systems using AI involves ongoing advancements to address emerging challenges and capitalize on evolving technologies. Further refinement of AI algorithms is crucial to enhance real-time adaptability and responsiveness, ensuring optimal traffic flow and safety. Integration with emerging technologies such as connected and autonomous vehicles will play a pivotal role in creating a seamless and integrated transportation ecosystem. Continued research and development will focus on addressing potential biases, improving data accuracy, and refining decision-making processes. Additionally, exploring the scalability of these systems to accommodate the growing complexity of urban environments and global urbanization trends will be a priority. Collaborations between researchers, policymakers, and industry stakeholders will be essential to shape the future trajectory of AI- powered traffic control, creating smarter and more sustainable urban mobility solutions. New Traffic & Parking Regulations Voted By Framingham City Council Take Effect September 1
FRAMINGHAM – New City of Framingham traffic & parking regulations take effect on September 1, 2024.
 The 11-member City Council voted unanimously this spring for the new traffic & parking regulations.
One of the major changes prohibits all vehicles with a commercial license plate from parking on City streets overnight and on Sundays.
The law specifically states, “No driver shall park or stand any commercial vehicle or trailer or semi-trailer (vehicles displaying a government-issued commercial license plate) between the hours of 11 p.m. of one day and 6 am. of the following day, Monday through Saturday or any time on Sunday.”
The new 72-page parking & traffic regulations were recommended to the City’s legislative division by the Framingham Traffic Commission. 
“The latest published version of Framingham’s traffic regulations was last revised in December 1988.  The Traffic Commission began working on a complete re-write in the fall of 2021,” said Framingham Traffic Commission Chair Brinsley Fuller.
   The Commission’s intent with the updated regulations, said Fuller, was to:
“The Traffic Commission is happy to have been a part of this process.  We thank the City Council for its support.  There have been many changes throughout the City since 1988 --- these regulations provide a current and reliable guide for the public and City Departments,” said Fuller.
The new regulations also increase the cost of a resident parking sticker from $20 to $25 per vehicle. Stickers are for calendar years; applicants must show proof of residency in the City of Framingham.
The new traffic & parking regulations also set a fee structure for violations ranging from $25 to $300.
The regulations prohibit residents from throwing “snow or ice in the area of the roadway, used by moving traffic. And no “person shall pile snow or ice in any roadway or any sidewalk near an intersection so as to obstruct the vision above a height of 4 feet within 20 feet of the intersection.”
The new traffic regulations apply only to the public right of way and not to publicly owned off-street areas, including municipal parking lots.
To view the 72-page parking regulations and the additional spreadsheets, visit City of Framingham, MA Parking (ecode360.com)
The information also can be found on the City of Framingham’s Traffic Commission webpage at Traffic Commission | City of Framingham, MA Official Website (framinghamma.gov)
Framingham Police are responsible for enforcing the City’s traffic and parking regulations.

tasks.question: In March-April 2024, a new traffic system in Chennai led to a 15% fuel consumption reduction. Given that in DC there were 52 traffic deaths in 2023, and in September 2024, the cost of a resident parking sticker in Framingham increased to $25 per vehicle, what is the result if you multiply the number of traffic deaths by the fuel consumption reduction percentage and then divide by the new parking sticker cost?
tasks.solution:
def solve():
    # Extracted numerical values from the document
    traffic_deaths_2023 = 52  # Number of traffic deaths in DC in 2023
    fuel_reduction_percentage = 15  # Reduction in fuel consumption in Chennai
    parking_sticker_cost_2024 = 25  # Cost of resident parking sticker in Framingham

    # Step 1: Multiply the number of traffic deaths by the fuel reduction percentage
    intermediate_result = traffic_deaths_2023 * fuel_reduction_percentage

    # Step 2: Divide the result by the new parking sticker cost in Framingham
    answer = intermediate_result / parking_sticker_cost_2024

    return answer

Factory Ordering a Car? These Are Wait Times We’re Seeing in 2024
Factory Ordering a Car? These Are Wait Times We’re Seeing in 2024
What vehicle are you interested in?
What's your zip code?
We track new car inventory monthly, and it’s been encouraging to see automakers like Ford and Toyota having more cars shipped to dealers. Still, automakers are selling every car they can make. With that said, more drivers are placing factory orders for vehicle builds that might not arrive until well into next year, or worse. Here’s how long car buyers are waiting for the vehicle they want.
Important note: These times are strictly for factory ordered cars. Many of these models are now available on dealer lots.
Kia and Hyundai Wait Times
Hyundai Motors owns 51% of Kia, and the two Korean automakers have grown increasingly close over the past decade. Today, many of their vehicles share components, and therefore have been similarly impacted by supply chain constraints.
These are the factory order wait times our team of Car Coaches is hearing in 2024:
Subaru Wait Times
Right now, buyers placing orders for a Subaru are regularly being told that the wait time for delivery will be between one and four months, and in some cases longer. Subaru was hit hard by the chip shortage, and has yet to pull out of the slump. These are the Subaru factory wait times we’re hearing today:
Toyota Factory Order Wait Times
How long you should expect to wait depends on the Toyota model and spec that you’ve ordered. For Toyota hybrids and plug-in hybrids, wait times are much longer. For the Toyota RAV4 Prime and Prius Prime, wait times are longest.
In 2024, these are common Toyota factory order wait times our team is hearing:
4Runner: 2-4 monthsGR86: 5-8 monthsCamry: 2-4 months / Hybrid 6+ monthsCorolla: 2-4 months / Hybrid 6+ monthsHighlander: 2-4 months / Hybrid 6+ monthsPrius: 4-6 months / Prime 8+ monthsRAV4: 2-4 months / Hybrid or Prime 8+ monthsSequoia: 2-4 months / Hybrid 6+ monthsSienna: 2-5 months / Hybrid 6+ monthsTacoma: 2-4 monthsTundra: 2-4 months / Hybrid 6+ monthsVenza: 2-4 months
Honda Wait Times
On average, Honda factory orders placed today can expect a four month wait before delivery. For the popular, newly redesigned Civic, the wait is more likely to be six months. Honda has been hit particularly hard by the chip shortage and pandemic-related disruptions. Japanese automakers were even dealt a blow from an earthquake earlier this year.
These are the Honda factory order wait times we’re seeing in 2024:
Accord: ImmediateCivic: 1-2 monthsCR-V: 1-2 monthsCR-V Hybrid: 3+ monthsOdyssey: 2-4 monthsPilot: 1-2 monthsRidgeline: Immediate
In 2024, the Honda Prologue electric crossover will arrive. Pre-orders are expected to open soon, so keep an eye out for that if you want to be first on the list for this GM-built Honda EV. It will qualify for at least half of the new EV tax credit.
See which new electric vehicles qualify for the new EV tax credit
Ram and Jeep Wait Times
For Jeep and Ram factory orders, wait times depend on what model and trim you want. Waiting three to four months for a Ram 1500 or Jeep Grand Cherokee is a lot easier to swallow if you’re getting a better deal with incentives.
These are the Ram truck factory wait times our team is encountering in 2024:
1500: 1-3 months2500: 2-4 months3500: 2-4 months
Ford Factory Orders Wait Times Faring Slightly Better
These are the Ford factory order wait times we’re seeing this year:
Bronco: 3+ monthsBronco Sport: 1-3 monthsF-150: 1-3 monthsF-250: 2-3 monthsF-350: 2-3 monthsF-450: 2-6 monthsMustang: ImmediateMustang Mach E: 1-3 months
Hybrids, Plug-In Hybrids and EVs Have the Longest Wait Times
We’re seeing wait times for popular hybrid vehicles extending up to one year for several automakers. It’s easy to forget that gas prices were over $5.00/gallon nationally just a few months ago, and that caused a massive spike in orders for more fuel-efficient vehicles.
Not only is demand higher, but OEMs are rationing their supplies of semiconductor chips and in some cases, even batteries.
In a silver lining to the confusing new EV tax credit, America will soon have its first used EV tax credit. The used EV tax credit began in January 2023, but only used EVs under $25,000 will qualify (if sold by a dealer, and the buyer meets income restrictions.) Learn more about the used EV tax credit and eligibility here.
Tesla Wait Times
Tesla regularly updates wait times for the Model Y, Model 3, Model S and Model X. As of 2024, here are Tesla wait times as shared on Tesla.com. Note that there are many possible configurations that affect estimated delivery dates, so check Tesla’s configurator for the most accurate estimate.
Taking Delivery After a Long Wait? Beware of the Infamous Dirt Mountain
Although Ford has somewhat improved factory order wait times in recent months, customers are still taking delivery of Broncos that had spent months waiting around at the so-called Dirt Mountain in Michigan. How could that impact those taking delivery of their beloved Ford Bronco? Field mice.
Anytime vehicles sit idly for months at a time, there’s the risk of rodents making the car their home. Before taking delivery, have all wires under the hood checked for signs of gnawing rodents. Ford even admitted in their earnings report that their number one challenge right now is quality control, and the infamous Dirt Mountain issues are certainly part of that. Of course these new vehicles are under warranty, but you’d hate to be left stranded with power failure shortly after driving your new car home.
